messageBody:
That sounds like two different things:

The logging, whether through log4j (which I also like) or something else, will provide debugging information to you.

The reports are useful for aggregate information (like how many failures and errors for X number of tests for the whole product suite, or whatever scope you run) and information about tests passed and failed (errors and failures).

For the tests that failed, you might use the information from the report (which will give you information around the issue - stack trace or failure information) or information from the log files (information for the entire run - you might be able to see the progression of state that led to the failure/error) to troubleshoot and fix.

I generally take the reports, or the result of an individual run, as my starting point, and then only look at the logging for the ones that failed in some way. If I have written my asserts well, I usually don't even need to look at the logging, because I will know exactly what went wrong.

Hope this helps and good luck on the migration.


Dianne
